Authors: Xiang Lu, Li Xue Niu, Wu Zhang
Title:
Leaf Spot of Vetiver Grass (Vetiveria zizanioides) Caused by
Microdochium vetiveriae sp. nov.
Keywords:
multilocus phylogeny, leaf spot, new taxon,
pathogenicity
Abstract:
Vetiver grass (Vetiveria. zizanioides) has been widely
used in the research of ecological environment management, restoration
of degraded ecosystems and essential oil extraction in recent years.
Lately, leaf spot disease of V. zizanioides caused by an unidentified
Microdochium sp. was observed in Zhanjiang, Guangdong provinces, China.
The disease initially appears as black brown, scattered small disease
spot. Under high temperature and moisture conditions, there are necrotic
spots with concentric circles and leaf becomes withered. Pathogenicity
tests indicated that the hyphae of Microdochium sp. isolated from
diseased V. zizanioides plants could cause leaf spot by inoculating
uninfected plants. Microscopic examination showed that the species was
morphologically distinct from related Microdochium species. Phylogenetic
tree inferred from the combined ITS, LSU, BTUB and RPB2 sequences also
revealed the strain to be a novel species of Microdochium sp. Combined
the result of phylogenetic, pathogenicity and morphological analyses, we
proposed a new species named M. vetiveriae for the pathogen of V.
zizanioides in southern China.
